elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of Cu(II) salts and 2,2′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic acid (2,2′,4,4′-H4bptc) in the presence of pyridyl ligands yielded three isomorphous 3D metal–organic coordination polymers formulated as [Cu2(2,2′,4,4′-bptc)(L) x ]·H2O [x = 2 for L = pyridine; x = 1 for L = bis(4-pyridyl)ethene and bis(4-pyridyl)ethane]. In the structure, the distorted paddlewheel [Cu2(COO)4] motif and the twisted Π-shaped 2,2′,4,4′-bptc serve as dissimilar 4-connected SBUs to generate a 3D [Cu2(2,2′,4,4′-bptc)] mother framework with the PtS topology, which selectively accommodates pyridine or bis(pyridyl) ligands of appropriate size.
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal reactions of Cu(II) salts and 2,2',4,4'-biphenyltetracarboxylic acid (2,2',4,4'-H4bptc) in the presence of pyridyl ligands yielded three isomorphous 3D metal-organic coordination polymers formulated as [Cu2(2,2',4,4'-bptc)(L) x ]⋅H2O [x = 2 for L = pyridine; x = 1 for L = bis(4-pyridyl)ethene and bis(4-pyridyl)ethane]. In the structure, the distorted paddlewheel [Cu2(COO)4] motif and the twisted Π-shaped 2,2',4,4'-bptc serve as dissimilar 4-connected SBUs to generate a 3D [Cu2(2,2',4,4'-bptc)] mother framework with the PtS topology, which selectively accommodates pyridine or bis(pyridyl) ligands of appropriate size.

elements.content:
The combination of the rhombic [Cu2(COO)4] unit and a twisted Π-shaped tetracarboxylate ligand leads to a mother framework showing size selectivity in incorporating auxiliary organic ligands.

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently attracted considerable interest, owing to their elegant framework topologies as well as their potential applications in gas storage, catalysis, drug delivery, luminescence, and magnetic materials. Thanks to the ability and versatility of the carboxylate group in forming strong coordination bonds and generating abundant structural motifs, a large number of MOFs with different dimensions and diverse topologies have been synthesized by using organic multicarboxylate ligands of different shapes, sizes, and rigidity/flexibility. Auxiliary organic ligands that complement or compete with carboxylate ligands in coordination can be introduced as additional and variable components to create new MOFs and to tune the dimensionality, topology, and properties. Among others, bis(4-pyridyl) ditopic ligands have most often been used as auxiliary bridges to link metal ions. The auxiliary bridges may serve to interlink low-dimensional motifs formed by multicarboxylate ligands into high-dimensional MOFs, as exemplified by the isoreticular series of 3D MOFs in which dicarboxylate-linked layers based on Zn2(COO)4 paddlewheel building units are pillared by bis(4-pyridyl) ligands of different sizes. The auxiliary bridges may also be incorporated within the multicarboxylate-linked frameworks without increasing dimensionality but increasing connectivity. In this case, the “mother frameworks” formed by multicarboxylic ligands impose a size/shape restriction on the auxiliary ligands, or in turn, the auxiliary ligands play structure-directing and templating roles in the formation of the mother frameworks. Only those with the right size and shape can be selectively incorporated in a rigid framework, but the selectivity may be less strict in a flexible framework. Investigations of the match between the auxiliary bridge with the mother framework are important to crystal engineering, adding to our understanding of the assembly processes and opening new possibilities of controlling topologies and properties. For instance, increasing the length of the auxiliary bridge in a flexible 3D mother framework can lead to dramatic changes in framework dimensions and in bulk magnetic properties, with the topology unchanged. We are interested in a tetracarboxylate ligand, 2,2′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylate (2,2′,4,4′-bptc, Scheme ), which has not been adequately explored in the domain of MOFs compared with the great attention on the 3,3′,5,5′ analogue. 2,2′,4,4′-bptc is unique in that the steric hindrance between the 2- and 2′-carboxylate groups makes the two benzene rings twist with respect to each other, so it can be regarded as a twisted Π-shaped organic SBU (secondary building unit). Such a unique organic SBU, combined with inorganic SBUs of different geometries, may lead to MOFs with unique topologies. Here we report three MOFs synthesized along this line, [Cu2(2,2′,4,4′-bptc)(L) x ]·H2O [x = 2 for 1, L = pyridine (py); x = 1 for 2 and 3, L = bis(4-pyridyl)ethene (bpe) and bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpa), respectively]. These MOFs have the same mother framework derived from the twisted Π-shaped SBU and the paddle-wheel-like [Cu2(COO)4] SBU. The assembly of the framework shows size selectivity among auxiliary pyridyl ligands, including pyridine (py, as terminal ligand) and bis(4-pyridyl) ligands (as bridging ligands).
elements.clean_text:
The combination of the rhombic [Cu2(COO)4] unit and a twisted Π-shaped tetracarboxylate ligand leads to a mother framework showing size selectivity in incorporating auxiliary organic ligands.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently attracted considerable interest, owing to their elegant framework topologies as well as their potential applications in gas storage, catalysis, drug delivery, luminescence, and magnetic materials. Thanks to the ability and versatility of the carboxylate group in forming strong coordination bonds and generating abundant structural motifs, a large number of MOFs with different dimensions and diverse topologies have been synthesized by using organic multicarboxylate ligands of different shapes, sizes, and rigidity/flexibility. Auxiliary organic ligands that complement or compete with carboxylate ligands in coordination can be introduced as additional and variable components to create new MOFs and to tune the dimensionality, topology, and properties. Among others, bis(4-pyridyl) ditopic ligands have most often been used as auxiliary bridges to link metal ions. The auxiliary bridges may serve to interlink low-dimensional motifs formed by multicarboxylate ligands into high-dimensional MOFs, as exemplified by the isoreticular series of 3D MOFs in which dicarboxylate-linked layers based on Zn2(COO)4 paddlewheel building units are pillared by bis(4-pyridyl) ligands of different sizes. The auxiliary bridges may also be incorporated within the multicarboxylate-linked frameworks without increasing dimensionality but increasing connectivity. In this case, the "mother frameworks" formed by multicarboxylic ligands impose a size/shape restriction on the auxiliary ligands, or in turn, the auxiliary ligands play structure-directing and templating roles in the formation of the mother frameworks. Only those with the right size and shape can be selectively incorporated in a rigid framework, but the selectivity may be less strict in a flexible framework. Investigations of the match between the auxiliary bridge with the mother framework are important to crystal engineering, adding to our understanding of the assembly processes and opening new possibilities of controlling topologies and properties. For instance, increasing the length of the auxiliary bridge in a flexible 3D mother framework can lead to dramatic changes in framework dimensions and in bulk magnetic properties, with the topology unchanged. We are interested in a tetracarboxylate ligand, 2,2',4,4'-biphenyltetracarboxylate (2,2',4,4'-bptc, Scheme ), which has not been adequately explored in the domain of MOFs compared with the great attention on the 3,3',5,5' analogue. 2,2',4,4'-bptc is unique in that the steric hindrance between the 2- and 2'-carboxylate groups makes the two benzene rings twist with respect to each other, so it can be regarded as a twisted Π-shaped organic SBU (secondary building unit). Such a unique organic SBU, combined with inorganic SBUs of different geometries, may lead to MOFs with unique topologies. Here we report three MOFs synthesized along this line, [Cu2(2,2',4,4'-bptc)(L) x ]⋅H2O [x = 2 for 1, L = pyridine (py); x = 1 for 2 and 3, L = bis(4-pyridyl)ethene (bpe) and bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpa), respectively]. These MOFs have the same mother framework derived from the twisted Π-shaped SBU and the paddle-wheel-like [Cu2(COO)4] SBU. The assembly of the framework shows size selectivity among auxiliary pyridyl ligands, including pyridine (py, as terminal ligand) and bis(4-pyridyl) ligands (as bridging ligands).

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>2,2′,4,4′-H<sub>4</sub>bptc Ligand</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2011-00752v_0006.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The compounds were synthesized under similar hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. They are isomorphous in the C2/c space group and exhibit 3D coordination networks. The 2,2′,4,4′-bptc ligand is bisected by the crystallographic 2-fold axis into two equivalent dicarboxylate moieties, and as expected, it adopts a twisted Π shape with the dihedral angle between the two benzene rings being in the range 52.6(8)–56.2(1)°. The 2-carboxylate group (O3–C5–O4, Figure ) bridges two metal ions in the syn–syn mode, while the 4-carboxylate (O1–C1–O2, Figure ) assumes a chelating–bridging mode, chelating one metal ion with highly asymmetric Cu–O distances and binding another metal ion through a μ-O atom (O1). The unique Cu(II) ion assumes a highly distorted octahedral geometry, completed by a chelating 4-carboxylate group, a μ-O from another 4-carboxylate, two O atoms from different 2-carboxylates, and a N atom from the pyridyl group. The O2 and O1C atoms from two 4-carboxylates define the significantly elongated axis of the Jahn–Teller distortion (Cu–Oaxial = 2.55 – 2.69 Å; for comparison, Cu–N/Oequatorial = 1.95–1.98 Å). The small bite angle (ca. 57°) of the chelating carboxylate group provokes severe angular distortion of the octahedral geometry around Cu(II).
elements.clean_text: The compounds were synthesized under similar hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. They are isomorphous in the C2/c space group and exhibit 3D coordination networks. The 2,2',4,4'-bptc ligand is bisected by the crystallographic 2-fold axis into two equivalent dicarboxylate moieties, and as expected, it adopts a twisted Π shape with the dihedral angle between the two benzene rings being in the range 52.6(8)-56.2(1)°. The 2-carboxylate group (O3-C5-O4, Figure ) bridges two metal ions in the syn-syn mode, while the 4-carboxylate (O1-C1-O2, Figure ) assumes a chelating-bridging mode, chelating one metal ion with highly asymmetric Cu-O distances and binding another metal ion through a μ-O atom (O1). The unique Cu(II) ion assumes a highly distorted octahedral geometry, completed by a chelating 4-carboxylate group, a μ-O from another 4-carboxylate, two O atoms from different 2-carboxylates, and a N atom from the pyridyl group. The O2 and O1C atoms from two 4-carboxylates define the significantly elongated axis of the Jahn-Teller distortion (Cu-Oaxial = 2.55 - 2.69 Å; for comparison, Cu-N/Oequatorial = 1.95-1.98 Å). The small bite angle (ca. 57°) of the chelating carboxylate group provokes severe angular distortion of the octahedral geometry around Cu(II).

elements.content: Coordination environments of the metal ion and the ligand in 1 (thermal ellipsoids at the 30% probability level). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (A) 0.5 + x, 0.5 – y, 0.5 + z; (B) 0.5 – x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; (C) 1 – x, –y, 1 – z; (D) –x, y, 0.5 – z.
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination environments of the metal ion and the ligand in 1 (thermal ellipsoids at the 30% probability level). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (A) 0.5 + x, 0.5 - y, 0.5 + z; (B) 0.5 - x, -0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; (C) 1 - x, -y, 1 - z; (D) -x, y, 0.5 - z.

elements.content: Two equivalent Cu(II) ions related by a crystallographic inversion center are quadruply bridged by two 2-carboxylates and two 4-carboxylates to give a centrosymmetric dinuclear [Cu2(COO)4] motif (Figure ), with a Cu···Cu separation of 2.88(3) Å. The motif is reminiscent of the well-known paddle-wheel [Cu2(COO)4] unit. While the typical paddle-wheel unit has four syn–syn bridging carboxylates and acts as a square SBU, the unique variant in our compounds features two syn–syn carboxylates and two highly asymmetric chelating–bridging carboxylates and acts as a rhombic SBU (Figure ). The SBUs are interlinked by the 2,2′,4,4′-bptc ligands to give a 3D framework, in which each dicopper SBU is connected to four 2,2′,4,4′-bptc ligands and each 2,2′,4,4′-bptc ligand to four dicopper SBUs (Figure , middle). The framework can be reduced into a 4-connected binodal 3D net with the pts (PtS) underlying net topology (point symbol 42·84) (Figure , left). The square and tetrahedral nodes for the pts net correspond to the dicopper units and the 2,2′,4,4′-bptc ligand, respectively. It is obvious that the twisted Π shape of the ligand is important to afford a highly distorted tetrahedral node.
elements.clean_text: Two equivalent Cu(II) ions related by a crystallographic inversion center are quadruply bridged by two 2-carboxylates and two 4-carboxylates to give a centrosymmetric dinuclear [Cu2(COO)4] motif (Figure ), with a Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation of 2.88(3) Å. The motif is reminiscent of the well-known paddle-wheel [Cu2(COO)4] unit. While the typical paddle-wheel unit has four syn-syn bridging carboxylates and acts as a square SBU, the unique variant in our compounds features two syn-syn carboxylates and two highly asymmetric chelating-bridging carboxylates and acts as a rhombic SBU (Figure ). The SBUs are interlinked by the 2,2',4,4'-bptc ligands to give a 3D framework, in which each dicopper SBU is connected to four 2,2',4,4'-bptc ligands and each 2,2',4,4'-bptc ligand to four dicopper SBUs (Figure , middle). The framework can be reduced into a 4-connected binodal 3D net with the pts (PtS) underlying net topology (point symbol 42⋅84) (Figure , left). The square and tetrahedral nodes for the pts net correspond to the dicopper units and the 2,2',4,4'-bptc ligand, respectively. It is obvious that the twisted Π shape of the ligand is important to afford a highly distorted tetrahedral node.

elements.content: Left: building blocks of the structures. Middle and right: 3D framework constructed from the building blocks.
elements.clean_text: 2  Left: building blocks of the structures. Middle and right: 3D framework constructed from the building blocks.

elements.content: The [Cu2(2,2′,4,4′-bptc)] n mother framework possesses 1D channels along the c direction (Figure ). The channels are mainly occupied by coordinated py, bpa, or bpe molecules, with a small portion of lattice water molecules. PLATON calculations omitting the lattice water indicated that the total guest-accessible void volume comprises only 8.4, 6.2, and 6.8% of the crystal volume for compounds 1, 2, and 3, respectively. In 2 and 3, the bpe or bpa ligand runs across the channel to link two metal ions from opposite walls. Taking into account the bis(pyridyl) bridges, the dicopper SBU should be regarded as a 6-connecting pseudo-octahedral node (Figure ), and hence, the resulting 3D framework becomes a 4,6-connected net with point symbol (42·52·62)2(42·56·64·73) (Figure , right). This topology (tcj-4,6-Pnna) has been theoretically derived as a subnet of the 6-connected tcj net (more details are given in the ) but not yet observed in real structures prior to this work.
elements.clean_text: The [Cu2(2,2',4,4'-bptc)] n  mother framework possesses 1D channels along the c direction (Figure ). The channels are mainly occupied by coordinated py, bpa, or bpe molecules, with a small portion of lattice water molecules. PLATON calculations omitting the lattice water indicated that the total guest-accessible void volume comprises only 8.4, 6.2, and 6.8% of the crystal volume for compounds 1, 2, and 3, respectively. In 2 and 3, the bpe or bpa ligand runs across the channel to link two metal ions from opposite walls. Taking into account the bis(pyridyl) bridges, the dicopper SBU should be regarded as a 6-connecting pseudo-octahedral node (Figure ), and hence, the resulting 3D framework becomes a 4,6-connected net with point symbol (42⋅52⋅62)2(42⋅56⋅64⋅73) (Figure , right). This topology (tcj-4,6-Pnna) has been theoretically derived as a subnet of the 6-connected tcj net (more details are given in the ) but not yet observed in real structures prior to this work.

elements.content: 3D frameworks of 1 (left) and 2 (right), with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity. The framework of 3 is similar to that of 2.
elements.clean_text: 3  3D frameworks of 1 (left) and 2 (right), with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity. The framework of 3 is similar to that of 2.

elements.content: 4,4-connected pts net for 1 (left) and 4,6-connected tcj-4,6-Pnna net for 2 and 3 (right).
elements.clean_text: 4  4,4-connected pts net for 1 (left) and 4,6-connected tcj-4,6-Pnna net for 2 and 3 (right).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (Figure S2 of the ) indicated that 1 releases water and py molecules upon heating to 85 and 205 °C, respectively, and decomposes upon further heating, but 2 and 3, after a slow and small weight loss before 200 °C, corresponding to water molecules, do not show evident weight loss until 290 °C. These observations clearly suggest that the auxiliary bridging ligand (bpa or bpe) across the channel helps much to stabilize the framework. The dehydration temperature of 2 and 3 is higher than that of 1, perhaps because the auxiliary bridging ligands are more efficient in blocking the solvent-accessible voids. PLATON calculations omitting the lattice water indicated that the solvent-accessible void size (∼40 Å3) in 2 and 3 is smaller than that (52 Å3) in 1. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements on the as-synthesized and dehydrated samples (see ) suggested that the frameworks remain unchanged upon the release of water molecules.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analyses (Figure S2 of the ) indicated that 1 releases water and py molecules upon heating to 85 and 205 °C, respectively, and decomposes upon further heating, but 2 and 3, after a slow and small weight loss before 200 °C, corresponding to water molecules, do not show evident weight loss until 290 °C. These observations clearly suggest that the auxiliary bridging ligand (bpa or bpe) across the channel helps much to stabilize the framework. The dehydration temperature of 2 and 3 is higher than that of 1, perhaps because the auxiliary bridging ligands are more efficient in blocking the solvent-accessible voids. PLATON calculations omitting the lattice water indicated that the solvent-accessible void size (~40 Å3) in 2 and 3 is smaller than that (52 Å3) in 1. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements on the as-synthesized and dehydrated samples (see ) suggested that the frameworks remain unchanged upon the release of water molecules.

elements.content: Interestingly, the 3D mother framework shows size selectivity in incorporating the pyridyl ligands. Compound 1 was synthesized as a pure phase in the copresence of py and 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy). The absence of bpy in the product indicates the selectivity for py over bpy. When bpy in the reaction systems was replaced by bpe or bpa, the product was 2 or 3, respectively, indicating that the selectivity is higher for bpe/bpa than for py. But we failed to isolate solid products when 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) was used in place of bpy. These experiments suggest a selectivity order of bpe/bpa > py > bpy/bpp. The selectivity has also been confirmed by a combinational synthetic experiment: the reaction in the copresence of four different pyridyl ligands (py, bpy, bpe, and bpp) yielded 2 as the only solid products. The selectivity obviously arises from the rigidity of the Cu(II)-2,2′,4,4′-bptc mother framework, which does not allow for significant changes in channel dimensions. Bpa and bpe are selected because they have the right size (N···N ≈ 9.3 Å for the trans conformation), well matching the Cu···Cu distance (∼13.2 Å in both 2 and 3) across the channels of the rigid frameworks. The channel is also suitable for the inclusion of coordinated py molecules without significant dimensional changes (the Cu···Cu distance across the channel in 1 is ∼13.0 Å). By contrast, bpy is too small and bpp too long to connect the opposite metal ions across the channel (bpp also has mismatching coordination orientation). The selective incorporation reflects the templating effects of the bpa, bpe, and py ligands in the assembly processes. It must be noted that all the compounds have been synthesized in the presence of py. We have been unable to obtain these compounds without py.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the 3D mother framework shows size selectivity in incorporating the pyridyl ligands. Compound 1 was synthesized as a pure phase in the copresence of py and 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy). The absence of bpy in the product indicates the selectivity for py over bpy. When bpy in the reaction systems was replaced by bpe or bpa, the product was 2 or 3, respectively, indicating that the selectivity is higher for bpe/bpa than for py. But we failed to isolate solid products when 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) was used in place of bpy. These experiments suggest a selectivity order of bpe/bpa > py > bpy/bpp. The selectivity has also been confirmed by a combinational synthetic experiment: the reaction in the copresence of four different pyridyl ligands (py, bpy, bpe, and bpp) yielded 2 as the only solid products. The selectivity obviously arises from the rigidity of the Cu(II)-2,2',4,4'-bptc mother framework, which does not allow for significant changes in channel dimensions. Bpa and bpe are selected because they have the right size (N⋅⋅⋅N ~ 9.3 Å for the trans conformation), well matching the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance (~13.2 Å in both 2 and 3) across the channels of the rigid frameworks. The channel is also suitable for the inclusion of coordinated py molecules without significant dimensional changes (the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance across the channel in 1 is ~13.0 Å). By contrast, bpy is too small and bpp too long to connect the opposite metal ions across the channel (bpp also has mismatching coordination orientation). The selective incorporation reflects the templating effects of the bpa, bpe, and py ligands in the assembly processes. It must be noted that all the compounds have been synthesized in the presence of py. We have been unable to obtain these compounds without py.

elements.content: In summary, three MOFs have been obtained from the tetracarboxylate ligand 2,2′,4,4′-bptc in the presence of different auxiliary pyridyl ligands. They contain the same mother framework with paddlewheel-like [Cu2(COO)4] as rhombic SBU and 2,2′,4,4′-bptc as twisted Π-shaped SBU. It has been demonstrated that only the auxiliary ligands that well match in size and shape with the channels in the mother framework can be selectively incorporated. The rigid mother framework with high size-selectivity in accommodating auxiliary ligands is in contrast with the flexible ones that are able to accommodate auxiliary bridging ligands of different length without topological changes.
elements.clean_text: In summary, three MOFs have been obtained from the tetracarboxylate ligand 2,2',4,4'-bptc in the presence of different auxiliary pyridyl ligands. They contain the same mother framework with paddlewheel-like [Cu2(COO)4] as rhombic SBU and 2,2',4,4'-bptc as twisted Π-shaped SBU. It has been demonstrated that only the auxiliary ligands that well match in size and shape with the channels in the mother framework can be selectively incorporated. The rigid mother framework with high size-selectivity in accommodating auxiliary ligands is in contrast with the flexible ones that are able to accommodate auxiliary bridging ligands of different length without topological changes.

elements.content:
X-ray crystallographic information files (CIF) and supplementary experimental data and graphics. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

The starting materials were all purchased from commercial sources. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (9.7 mg, 0.040 mmol), 2,2′,4,4′-H4bptc (6.6 mg, 0.020 mmol), and 4,4′-bipyridine (3.1 mg, 0.020 mmol) in H2O/py (v/v = 5/1, 6 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 130 °C for 96 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. Blue cube-shaped crystals of 1 were obtained in a yield of ca. 78%. Compounds 2 and 3 were synthesized in yields of ca. 50 and 61%, respectively, by similar hydrothermal procedures using bpa and bpe, respectively, instead of 4,4′-bipyridine. Analytical and IR data are given in the .

Blue cube-shaped crystals of 1 were obtained in a yield of ca. 78%. Compounds 2 and 3 were synthesized in yields of ca. 50 and 61%, respectively, by similar hydrothermal procedures using bpa and bpe, respectively, instead of 4,4'-bipyridine. Analytical and IR data are given in the .

elements.content: Crystal data: 1, C26H18Cu2N2O9, M r = 629.52, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a = 14.707(11), b = 11.252(8), c = 16.704(9) Å, β = 117.08(5)°, V = 2461(3) Å3, Z = 4, μ = 1.788 mm–1, D c = 1.699 g cm–3, T = 296(2) K. 6380 reflections measured, 2519 unique (R int = 0.0345) used in all calculations, R 1 = 0.0379 for 2101 reflections with I > 2σ(I) and wR 2 = 0.1159 for all data. 2, C28H18Cu2N2O9, M r = 653.54, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a = 14.8192(5), b = 11.0158(4), c = 16.5703(7) Å, β = 115.4720(10)°, V = 2442.08(16) Å3, Z = 4, μ = 1.806 mm–1, D c = 1.778 g cm–3, T = 296(2) K. 15099 reflections measured, 2510 unique (R int = 0.0218) used in all calculations, R 1 = 0.0368 for 2294 reflections with I > 2σ(I) and wR 2 = 0.1067 for all data. 3, C28H20Cu2NO9, M r = 655.56, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a = 14.7964(6), b = 11.0068(5), c = 16.5455(10) Å, β = 115.3700(10)°, V = 2434.7(2) Å3, Z = 4, μ = 1.811 mm–1, D c = 1.783 g cm–3, T = 296(2) K. 15239 reflections measured, 2654 unique (R int = 0.0578) used in all calculations, R 1 = 0.0462 for 1890 reflections with I > 2σ(I) and wR 2 = 0.1388 for all data.

X-ray crystallographic information files (CIF) and supplementary experimental data and graphics. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

The starting materials were all purchased from commercial sources. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (9.7 mg, 0.040 mmol), 2,2′,4,4′-H4bptc (6.6 mg, 0.020 mmol), and 4,4′-bipyridine (3.1 mg, 0.020 mmol) in H2O/py (v/v = 5/1, 6 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 130 °C for 96 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. Blue cube-shaped crystals of 1 were obtained in a yield of ca. 78%. Compounds 2 and 3 were synthesized in yields of ca. 50 and 61%, respectively, by similar hydrothermal procedures using bpa and bpe, respectively, instead of 4,4′-bipyridine. Analytical and IR data are given in the .
cln_elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic information files (CIF) and supplementary experimental data and graphics. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

The starting materials were all purchased from commercial sources. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (9.7 mg, 0.040 mmol), 2,2',4,4'-H4bptc (6.6 mg, 0.020 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (3.1 mg, 0.020 mmol) in H2O/py (v/v = 5/1, 6 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 130 °C for 96 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. Blue cube-shaped crystals of 1 were obtained in a yield of ca. 78%. Compounds 2 and 3 were synthesized in yields of ca. 50 and 61%, respectively, by similar hydrothermal procedures using bpa and bpe, respectively, instead of 4,4'-bipyridine. Analytical and IR data are given in the .

metadata.title: Selective Incorporation of Auxiliary Organic Ligands in Metal–Organic Frameworks Based on Twisted Π-Shaped Building Blocks
